What should the project manager do?

questions.question_text:
A new project has been kicked off following a planning session. The project is under direct oversight of an executive in the organization. After a review meeting, the project manager overhears an executive request a dashboard from one of the team members to show the overall project status.
What should the project manager do?

choices.C: Ask the team member to develop a dashboard to fulfill the request
choices.A: Update the stakeholder engagement assessment matrix
choices.D: Tell the team member to route the request through the project manager
choices.B: Update the communications management plan to include informal requests

comments.content: I am confused between B and D
good luck with that in the real world
Exam environment isn't the 'real world' - thus, the PM Mindset.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Gonna go with B. None of these answers will ever be "Tell the team member to ____" They want you to approach it from the view of a servant leader.

comments.content: I'm going with D. This guy is mostly wrong

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
As the project manager, it is important to establish communication channels and ensure that all requests are properly routed through the appropriate channels. The project manager should be the primary point of contact for all project communications and requests, and should coordinate with the team member to develop the dashboard and provide the executive with the status update. By directing the team member to route the request through the project manager, the project manager ensures that they are aware of all project activities and can properly manage project communications.

Selected Answer: D
This option involves instructing the team member to politely redirect the executive’s request to the project manager. By doing so, the project manager can then take ownership of fulfilling the request—whether by preparing the dashboard themselves or coordinating with the team to do so. This ensures that all project-related communication flows through the appropriate channels, maintaining consistency, accuracy, and the project manager’s authority.
This is B. Reality is D. If you act like B, your desk will disappear.

Selected Answer: D
As the project manager, it's important to ensure that all requests and changes go through the proper channels to maintain control and visibility over the project. Allowing team members to receive and fulfill ad-hoc requests from executives or stakeholders can lead to scope creep, confusion, and potential delays.

By directing the team member to route the request through the project manager, you can:

- Ensure that all requests are properly documented and prioritized
- Maintain control over the project scope and objectives
- Provide a single point of contact for stakeholders and executives
- Keep the project team focused on the agreed-upon goals and tasks

Selected Answer: D
PM is tha contact point for executive request the report

Selected Answer: B
The project manager should **B. Update the communications management plan to include informal requests**. The communications management plan outlines how project communications will be planned, structured, monitored, and controlled. If executives are making informal requests, it's important to capture this in the plan to ensure that all communication needs are met and that there's a clear process for handling such requests. This can help prevent confusion, ensure that all stakeholders are kept informed, and maintain the integrity of the project management process.

Selected Answer: B
B. Update the communications management plan to include informal requests.

The reason being, a communications management plan outlines the methods, tools, frequency, and other parameters for how communication will occur during the project. When a stakeholder, in this case an executive, expresses a need for a specific type of communication (like a dashboard for project status), it's a cue for the project manager to ensure that the communications management plan reflects these needs to ensure clarity and consistency in future communications. It helps to prevent misunderstandings and ensures that all stakeholders receive the information they need in the format they prefer.

A project manager is managing a project which has a very complex and long execution period. Although the project is mostly predictive, the team was able to break the design and execution into smaller packages using a hybrid framework. The business wants to keep track of the value delivered by this framework application but there is no defined set of measurable items for the framework.
What should the project manager do first?

choices.D: Research which templates of reports were used the most for this framework and incorporate them into the project
choices.C: Use the same benefits tracking process from the last predictive project and add this to the monthly status report
choices.B: Create a report based on the work breakdown structure (WBS) and update it on a regular basis.
choices.A: Work with the stakeholders to determine which measurable benefits can be tracked and assign an accountable person to monitor and report them

PMBOK: Five alternative strategies may be considered for dealing with opportunities, as follows:
uu Escalate. This risk response strategy is appropriate when the project team or the project sponsor agrees that an opportunity is outside the scope of the project or that the proposed response would exceed the project manager’s authority. Escalated opportunities are managed at the program level, portfolio level, or other relevant part of the organization, and not on the project level. The project manager determines who should be notified
about the opportunity and communicates the details to that person or part of the organization. It is important that ownership of escalated opportunities is accepted by the relevant party in the organization. Opportunities are usually escalated to the level that matches the objectives that would be affected if the opportunity occurred.
Escalated opportunities are not monitored further by the project team after escalation, although they may be recorded in the risk register for information.

comments.content: Even with a positive benefit, its a risk, and risks usually follow some form of tracking/escalation policy if they become an issue. Change control procedures will apply to this. I'd assume the next best answer is to let the team take more time to complete everything, however this is something you should avoid. Parkinson's law basically says that any amount of time given for work completion will usually be used up. For example if you give someone an 8 hour workday, but they finish most of the work in 2 hours, they will stretch that last bit of work out to the last hour, this is why you never want to take shortcuts and just throw buffer numbers out there, because each "buffer" you give someone is basically adding cost to it that probably wouldn't be necessary in the first place.
